Running head:
Preparation of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles used for humic acid adsorption

Highlights:
 Adsorption of humic acid from aqueous solution using Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has
been investigated.
 Experimental equilibrium data follows Langmuir isotherm model.  The kinetic data of adsorption process follows pseudo-second-order kinetic model.  The Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has a potential of being used as an adsorbent.
Abstract
The adsorbent of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles have been prepared. In this process,
these materials were initially synthesized by chemical co-precipitation and then cross-linked with chitosan to coat on the surface of Fe3O4 nano-particles. The characterization of the synthesized Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was performed using FTIR, XRD, TEM, EDX, BET and TGA. Finally, the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles were used for the adsorption of humic acid (HA) from aqueous solutions using batch adsorption technique. The influences of contact time, pH, adsorbent dosages, initial concentration of HA and temperatures on the adsorption process were studied. The adsorption isotherms were better fitted by Langmuir isotherm with the adsorption capacity was found to be 44.84 mg/g. The results of the kinetic study showed that the adsorption of HA onto Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles could be described by the pseudo second order kinetic model with a rate constant in the range of 0.032 to 0.104 g.mg-1.min-1, respectively. Thermodynamic parameters data indicated that the HA adsorption process was non spontaneous and endothermic under the experimental conditions, with the values of Gibbs free energy (ΔGo) were in the range of 2.92 to 4.65 kJ mol-1; as well as the values of enthalpy (ΔHo), entropy (ΔSo) and the activation energy (Ea) were found to be 21.80 kJ mol -1, 57.55 J mol-1 and 19.27 kJ mol-1, respectively. The computational chemistry study showed that the interaction between adsorbent and HA was occurred through the interaction between amine groups of
chitosan and phenol groups of HA. The adsorption of HA from real sample using the prepared adsorbents showed that the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has higher adsorption percentages than both Fe3O4 nano-particles and pure chitosan.
Keywords: adsorption, chitosan, Fe3O4, humic acid, hybrid

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Humic acid (HA) is a subclass of humic substances and accounts for a significant portion
of the dissolved organic matter found in peat water. The chemical and physical characteristics of humic acid are strongly dependent on the source they originated. HA is natural occurring organic molecule formed by the breakdown of animal and vegetable matters and other biological activities of microorganisms in the environment. The presence of humic acids in water introduce a yellowish to brown color and pose a serious environmental problem, particularly in drinking water treatment because of their taste and odor. They also tend to react with a variety of oxidants and disinfectants used for the purification of drinking water forming carcinogenic disinfection byproducts (DBPs) such as trihalomethanes and haloacetic acids (Hamid et al., 2011; Park and Yoon, 2009; Rojas et al., 2011; Sonea et al., 2010).
Recently, there are several methods used to remove humic substance, especially humic acid
as main component from peat water, such as coagulation-flocculation (Park and Yoon, 2009; Rojas et al., 2011), photocatalysis (Sonea et al., 2010), electro-coagulation processes (Ghernaout et al., 2009) and membrane technology (Hamid et al., 2011; Park and Yoon, 2009; Rojas et al., 2011). However, these methods are not widely used due to their high cost and economic disadvantages.
Adsorption is a well-known separation process and is widely used to remove certain classes
of chemical pollutants from water. It has been found to be superior to other techniques for water re-use in terms of initial cost, flexibility and simplicity of design, ease of operation and high efficiency (Toor and Jin, 2012). Although the adsorption technique is versatile and is easy to adopt in practical forms, the adsorbent materials are either costly or cannot be regenerated in the large-scale applications.
Chitosan is a natural adsorbent due to the presence of the amine (-NH2) and hydroxyl (-
OH) groups. These groups serve as the adsorption sites for many adsorbates (Chang and Juang, 2004). However, raw chitosan presents some major problems in adsorption process, i.e. (i) weak mechanical property, (ii) easy dissolution in acidic media, (iii) low specific gravity, (iv) high swelling ratios, which limits its use in either batch or column modes (Dong et al., 2014; Jiang et al., 2013). In addition, conventional bioadsorbents based on cellulose are difficult to be separated and recovered except by high speed centrifugation or filtration and this lead to limit the practical application of these bioadsorbents. For above-mentioned reasons, it is significant and necessary to explore environment-friendly bioadsorbents based on raw chitosan that possess higher adsorption capacities and excellent separation property.
Currently, magnetic metal oxides such as Fe3O4 nano-particles are in focus as powerful
adsorbents due to their large specific surface area and small internal diffusion resistance (Mohammadi et al., 2014). As comparison, some researchers have also studied the magnetic carbon nanotubes as the pollutant removals (Ma et al., 2013; Yu, et al., 2012a; Yu, et al., 2012b), which showed similar activity to magnetic metal oxides due to the large specific area and specific pore size suitable for the pollutant adsorbent. These magnetite nano-particles can adsorb pollutant from aqueous solutions and then be separated from the water with a simple magnetic
process. However, such ultrafine particles face great challenges in their practical applications. The first challenge is how to separate Fe3O4 nano-particles from bulky solution in an effective and economical manner. It is generally known that the acting force of the magnetic field on the particles is directly proportional to particle size (Kelland, 1998; Jiang et al., 2012) and cannot be effectively separated in a moderate magnetic field (Jiang et al., 2012; Kelland, 1998; Yavuz et al., 2006). In addition, nano-sized Fe3O4 particles tend to aggregate into bulky particles and thus result in a significant decrease in adsorption capacity. Consequently, how to develop Fe3O4based adsorbents of high capacity and feasible separation is becoming an interesting but challenging topic in the field of environmentally functional materials.
Many researchers have been focused on modification of the Fe3O4 nano-particles to
provide a better surface specificity for the removal of different pollutants from aqueous solutions. For this purpose, a wide range of chemicals, such as polyacrylic acid (Zhao et al., 2013), humic acid (Zhang et al., 2013), carboxymethyl-cyclodextrin (Badruddoza et al., 2010), graphene oxide (Chang et al., 2012; Xie et al., 2012), zinc oxide (Singh et al., 2013), multi-wall carbon nano-tube (Ai et al., 2011), graphite (Li et al., 2014), chitosan (Cao et al., 2014), activated carbon (Liu et al., 2010; Do et al., 2011), alginate (Mohammadi et al., 2014; Srivastava et al., 2012), surfactant (Shariati et al., 2011; Wang et al., 2012) and polymers (Bhaumik et al., 2013; Han et al., 2013; Shuang et al., 2013) have been used to modify the surface of Fe3O4 magnetic nano-particles.
This paper reports on the preparation of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles using an in
situ co-precipitation method, as a magnetic adsorbent for the removal of HA from aqueous solution. Effects of various experimental conditions such as contact time, initial concentration, pH and adsorbent dosages, on the adsorption were evaluated through a batch equilibrium
technique. In addition, the adsorption of peat water (the real water sample) has also been performed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
The reagents used for the preparation of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles were
FeSO4.7H2O (Aldrich), FeCl3·6H2O (Aldrich), ammonium hydroxide, 25% (Merck), epichlorohydrin (Merck), chitosan (Mr = 500 kDa) with 85% degree of deacetylation was obtained by Aldrich, acetic acid (Merck), and ethanol (Merck). Deionized water was used in all experiments. For the adsorption experiments, humic acid (Merck) was chosen as the model organic pollutant. The real sample, peat water was collected in November 2014 from Rimbo Panjang, a sub district of Kampar in Riau Province, Indonesia, which is a source for water supply. The peat water was collected in a cleaned plastic container and then delivered to the laboratory. After filtration through 0.45 μm hydrophilic PTFE membrane filters (Millipore, JHWP09025), the filtered water was stored in brown glass bottles at 4 °C to minimize changes of its properties, which is hereafter referred to as raw water and used in the experiments. The water quality of the peat water can be seen in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fe3O4 nano-particles preparation
sections.text:
The synthesis of the Fe3O4 nano-particles were based on the study carried out by Dong et
al. (2014) with some modifications. In a typical procedure, a mixture of FeCl3.6H2O (0.046 mol) and FeSO4.7H2O (0.023 mol) was dissolved into 150 mL deionized water in 250 mL threenecked flask and N2 was imported for 3 minutes to extrude the air. Then 20 mL ammonium
hydroxide (25%) was added quickly into the iron solution under vigorous stirring. After 30 minutes, 3 mL epichlorohydrin was added into the mixture to modify the Fe3O4 nano-particles and the mixture was heated to 75 oC for 1 h under N2 atmosphere then cooled to room temperature. The Fe3O4 nano-particles were collected through magnetic separation and washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, respectively, then dried at vacuum conditions.
Table 1
The characteristics of peat water (a real sample of humic acid)

sections.heading: 2.3. Synthesis of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
sections.text:
Chitosan (0.5 g) in 100 mL of 1.0 wt% acetic acid solution, 1.5 g modified Fe3O4 nano-
particles were added into a three-necked flask and then the mixture was refluxed for 4 h at 65 oC and pH 6. After the completion of the reaction, the composites were collected through magnetic separation and were washed by deionized water and ethanol for several times. The products were dried in vacuo.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization
sections.text:
In order to confirm the coating of chitosan onto Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material, the
compositions of the nano-particles were examined in dried KBr powder by recording the infrared spectra over the frequency range of 4000-400 cm-1 using a Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrophotometer model 8300 IR-TF (Shimadzu, Japan). The crystalline structure of the synthesized Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) RINT 2000 (Rigaku Instrument Corp., Japan) with Cu Kα (λ=0.15406 nm) radiation at 40 kV and 100
mA at room temperature. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) were used to observe the morphology of the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material. The elemental composition of the surface of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material was determined with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The surface area and average pore diameter of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid materials were determined using a Micromeritics Gemini 2370 (USA) gas adsorption surface analyzer according BET multipoint technique. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Perkin Elmer TGA-7 thermo gravimetric analyzer to determine the magnetite content.

sections.heading: 2.5. Adsorption studies
sections.text:
Each 0.05 g of the Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles powdered were added
to 50 mL humic acid (HA) solution in a 100 mL Erlenmeyer flasks placed in thermostatic shaker bath (Innova 3000). The suspension was shaken at 150 rpm for different intervals of time ranging from 5 to 120 min at room temperature and pH 4. After shaking for specific time, the suspension was extracted and then separated by using magnet force. The HA concentration in the clear solution in mg/L was determined employing colorimetry method using ultraviolet-visible
spectrophotometer model UV-Vis 1601 (Shimadzu, Japan) at the  254 nm (Zulfikar et al.,
2013). The percent adsorption of HA was calculated using the following equation:
% Adsorption = 100x Ci
CeCi  (1)
where Ci and Ce are initial and final concentration of HA (mg/L) in solution, respectively. The adsorption capacity of an adsorbent obtained from the mass balance on the sorbate in a system with solution volume V, which expressed as:
qe (mg/g) = x m
CeCi  V (2)
where Ci and Ce are the initial and final concentration of HA (mg/L) in solution, respectively. V is the volume of solution (L) and m is mass of materials (g) used.
The effect of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles dosage on adsorption of HA from its
solution was examined by varying the mass of adsorbent from 0.01 to 0.1 g at pH 4.00 and sample volume was 50 mL. The adsorption procedure was similar to that of the effect of agitation time. The effect of pH on HA adsorption by Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was studied by varying the solution pH from 2 to 10. The pH of the HA solution was adjusted using 0.1 M HCl or 0.1 M NaOH and measured by using a pH-meter (Orion Aqualytic AL15). The effect of temperature on HA adsorption using Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was studied by performing experiments at 25 oC, 45 oC, 55 oC and 65 oC. At a given temperature and pH 4.00, the adsorbent dosage was 0.05 g. The procedure was similar to that described for the effect of agitation time.

sections.heading: 2.6. Computational chemistry
sections.text:
In this study, we undertook a theoretical investigation of possible interaction between HA
and chitosan using the first principles calculation. In the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nanoparticles, we believe the interaction mainly occurred between the chitosan layer and HA. We took some possible interactions between active sites of chitosan and HA as initial configuration. Then we did geometry optimization and compare the converged energy. The total energy of each model was determined by Hartree-Fock theory as implemented in GAUSSIAN 09 package (Frisch et al., 2009). The model of chitosan and HA in our calculation can be seen in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1. Structure of dimer chitosan (a) and HA (b). Grey, red, blue and white spheres represent carbon, oxygen, nitrogen and hydrogen atoms, respectively

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
sections.text:
To confirm the presence of chitosan at Fe3O4, FTIR analyses were done and are shown in
Fig. 2. The FTIR spectrum of the magnetite (Fe3O4) (Fig. 2b) demonstrated peaks at wavenumber of 578 and 464 cm-1 that are considered to arise from Fe-O bands in tetrahedral and octahedral sites, confirming the spinel type structure of Fe3O4 (Mohammadi et al., 2014; Srivastava et al., 2012). The FTIR spectra of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles before and after HA adsorption are shown in Fig. 2c and 2d. The spectrum of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles before adsorption displays a number of absorption peaks, an indication of different types of functional groups present in the crosslinked beads. The broad band appearing in the range of 3000-3600 cm1 can be attributed to stretching vibrations of O-H and amino groups of chitosan. The asymmetric and symmetric aliphatic C-H stretching bands were observed at 2931 cm-1. The bands at 1625 and 1529 cm-1 were related to the C=O stretching vibration of amide and the bending vibration of -NH2 groups of chitosan, respectively, and 1068 cm -1 represented the C-O stretching vibration of C-OH of chitosan (Cao et al., 2014; Li et al., 2011).
Fig. 2. The FTIR spectra of (a) chitosan (b), Fe3O4, (b) Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles, and (d) Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles after HA adsorption
Meanwhile, the strong characteristic adsorption peaks at the wavenumbers of 574 and 455
cm-1 corresponding to the Fe-O bond vibration of Fe3O4 appeared in the IR spectrum of Fe3O4chitosan hybrid nano-particles (Fig. 2 c), further indicating that Fe3O4 in Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has been in situ formed (Cao et al., 2014).
The FTIR spectrum for HA loaded Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles (Fig. 2d) showed
no shift in wavenumbers or appearance of new peaks, indicating that chemical interaction did not occur between the adsorbent and HA. Therefore, the adsorption of HA on Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles is physical in nature.
The crystalline structure of Fe3O4, chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was
characterized by XRD as shown in Fig. 3. The diffraction peaks at 30.22o (220), 35.66o (311), 43.25o (400), 53.55o (422), 57.25o (511) and 62.88o (440) are associated with Fe3O4. The observed peaks of Fe3O4 were consistent with the database in JCPDS file (PCPDFWIN v.2.02, PDF NO. 85-1436) and also reveal that the pure Fe3O4 phase is a spinal structure (Bhaumik et al., 2013; Cao et al., 2014; Mohammadi et al., 2014). The XRD pattern of chitosan (curve in Fig. 3) showed a typical peak at 2θ = 20.6°. In the XRD pattern of as prepared Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles, the broad peak was observed at around 2θ = 21.6o, but it became much lower and wider which was corresponding to chitosan (Cao et al., 2014). Meanwhile, six diffraction peaks were also observed at 2θ = 29.9°, 35.6°, 43.1°, 53.5°, 57.2°, and 62.7°, corresponding to (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), and (440) crystal planes of Fe3O4, respectively. These revealed that the crystal structure of Fe3O4 in Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was also a cubic spinel structure. The average diameter of the Fe3O4 and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles calculated by using Debye-Scherrer’s equation to the (311) peak is about 24 and 29 nm, respectively.
Fig. 3. XRD patterns of Fe3O4, chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material
The morphology of the samples was investigated by TEM and shown in Fig. 4a-b. From
Fig. 4a shows that the Fe3O4 nano-particles suffered severe aggregation in water due to the interaction between the magnetic dipoles of the Fe3O4 nano-particles. The TEM image of Fe3O4chitosan hybrid nano-particles exhibits a well defined core-shell structure (Fig. 4b).
One of characterization methods to reveal the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
morphology pattern can be performed by quantitatively analyzing the TEM images. TEM images were converted into line profiles representing the gray value intensity (Collins, 2007; Schneider et al., 2012). The gray values were extracted along the preselected line across the TEM images. The TEM image has different gray value intensity at different area. A lower gray value intensity corresponds to darker area whereas lighter area has a higher gray value intensity. Plot of these intensities along a line crossing the image forms a characteristic pattern specific for a certain type morphology. For example, U-like and W-like plot correspond to dense (non-porous) and hollow type material, respectively. The core-shell type material has pattern almost similar to the U-like pattern (Fig. 4c) and characterized by concentric sphere morphology. This morphology has a denser core than the outer part. Those two patterns are useful for identifying the Fe3O4chitosan hybrid nano-particles morphology. As we look at Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles profile (Fig. 4d), the pattern shows similar shape as core-shell type material.
The Fe3O4 nano-particle size of the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles is estimated to be
about 15 nm, which is close to the result obtained by means of XRD.
Fig. 4. TEM images of (a) Fe3O4, (b) Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles and the morphology nomenclatures for core-shell (c) and reproduced Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
To confirm the coated chitosan molecules on Fe3O4 nano-particles, energy dispersive X-
rays (EDX) was used to analyze the elemental constituents of the Fe3O4 nano-particles before and after coated. Fig. 5a shows O peak at 0.525 and Fe peak at 6.398 keV for Fe3O4 nanoparticles. C peak at 0.277, O peak at 0.525 and Fe peak at 6.398 keV for Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles (Fig. 5b). This feature indicated that the EDX analysis provides a direct evidence for coated chitosan onto Fe3O4 nano-particles surface. The element N cannot be detected because the number or N within the chitosan as polymers is less than C and O atoms. Furthermore, when chitosan was being hybrid to Fe3O4 then the interaction between atom N of chitosan and Fe3O4 would form via dipole-dipole interactions, therefore this interaction would shield the N atoms to be detected during the EDX analysis.
Fig. 5. EDX curve of (a) Fe3O4, and (b) Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
The average pore width of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was 1.5 nm. Also, the
SBET, pore volume and average pore diameter of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles and Fe3O4 nano-particles are listed in Table 2. Decrease in SBET and pore width of Fe3O4 nano-particles with chitosan coated could be due to the Fe3O4 nano-particles pore covered by chitosan which resulted in decreasing of nitrogen molecules adsorption in pores.
To evaluate the thermal stability of the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles, TGA analysis
was carried out under nitrogen atmosphere from 25 oC to 800 oC. The TGA curves of the Fe3O4,
chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material are illustrated in Fig. 6. The TGA curve of the Fe3O4 (Fig. 6a) showed about 11% weight loss over the temperature ranging from room temperature to 380 oC, resulting from the loss of residual water in the sample (Cao et al., 2014).
Table 2
Physical properties of prepared Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
Fig. 6. TGA curves of (a) Fe3O4, (b) chitosan and (c) Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles
The pure chitosan (curve c) shows slower weight loss in the region between 160 oC and
270 oC due to the decomposition of low molecular weight species. Thermal decomposition is more marked in the region between 170 oC and 450 oC relating to the complex dehydration of the saccharide rings, depolymerization, and decomposition of the acetylated and deacetylated units of the polymer (Al-Sagheer and Muslim, 2010). Afterwards, a second process characterized by the release of CH4 took place in the range 450-850 oC (highest rate at ca. 590 oC) and caused a modest weight loss (9 wt.%). This step suggests that a further modification of the material occurs when the structure is almost completely reduced causing the production of methane and the consequent formation of a graphite-like structure via dehydrogenation mechanism, as suggested in the literature (Corazzari et al., 2015). The TGA curve of the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material (Fig. 6b) was very different from that of the Fe3O4. Three stages of weight loss were observed in the TGA curve of the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material. The first stage was about 12% weight loss from room temperature to 270 °C, as a result of the evaporation of adsorbed water. The other two
stages of main weight loss at 300-400 °C and 700-900 °C were caused by the decomposition of the chitosan in the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid material (Cao et al., 2014; Li et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Effect of contact time and initial concentration of HA
sections.text:
The effect of contact time on the removal of HA by nano-Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-
particles is given in Fig. 7. The contact time curves show rapid adsorption of HA in the first 30 min, thereafter, the adsorption rate decreases gradually. This was attributed to that there were plenty of available adsorption sites. With the adsorption process proceeding, the adsorption sites were occupied gradually and the percent removal elevated slowly and the adsorption reaches its equilibrium in 60 min (optimum contact time).
The effect of initial concentration on the removal of HA by nano-Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid
nano-particles is shown in Fig. 7. It is also evident from the figure that the percentage HA removal decreased with the increase in initial HA concentration. This is so because the initial HA concentration provides the driving force to overcome the resistance to the mass transfer of HA between the aqueous and the solid phase. At lower concentrations, all sorbate ions present in the sorption medium could interact with the binding sites, hence higher percentage adsorption results. For constant dosage of adsorbent, at higher initial HA concentration, the available adsorption sites of adsorbent become fewer and hence the percentage adsorption of the HA showed a decreasing trend.
Fig. 7. The effect of agitation time and concentration on HA removal from aqueous solution (volume 50 mL, dosage 0.05 g, pH 4.00, shaking speed 150 rpm and temp. 25 oC)

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Effect of adsorbent dosage
sections.text:
A plot of percent removal of HA versus adsorbent dosage is shown in Fig. 8. As can be
seen, the percent removal of HA increases with the increase in the amount of adsorbent. This can be attributed to the increasing of adsorbent surface area and the availability of more adsorption sites. However, with increasing amount of adsorbent up to 0.05, the adsorption efficiency of HA did not change significantly.
Fig. 8. The effect of adsorbent dosage on HA removal from aqueous solution (contact time: 60 min., volume 50 mL, conc. 20 mg/L, pH 4.00, shaking speed 150 rpm, and temp. 25 oC)

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Effect of pH
sections.text:
The pH value of the peat water is an important factor for the determination of the HA
removal. The effect of the initial pH on the percent removal of HA by Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was studied over the pH range from 2 to 10. The results are shown in Fig. 9. It is obvious from Fig. 9 that the At low pH values (2-4), the protonation of the amino groups in Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles causes electrostatic attraction between NH 3+ groups of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles and the RCOO − groups of humic acid. This leads to a significant increase in the amount of humic acid adsorbed.
At higher pH however, the increase of solution pH reduces the concentration of H+, thus,
the adsorption of humic acid decreases with the increase in the pH value of solution. At pH greater than 4, Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles showed very low amount of humic acid adsorption (Fig. 9). This is due to the increase concentration of hydroxide ions in the solution, causing the deprotonation of the amino groups in Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles. This
results in repulsive effect between deprotonated amino group with RCOO− and RO− groups in humic acid, hence the adsorption capacity was greatly reduced. Based on Fig. 9, it was found that the optimum pH for adsorption of humic acid on Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles is at pH 4.00. Since carboxylic groups start to dissociate at pH 4-6, it is believed that at pH 4.00, the electrostatic attraction between deprotonated carboxylic groups of humic acid and protonated amino groups of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was strongest, hence maximum adsorption capacity of humic acid was observed at this pH value.
Fig. 9. The effect of pHs on HA removal from aqueous solution (contact time: 60 min., volume 50 mL, conc. 20 mg/L, dosage 0.05 g, shaking speed 150 rpm, and temp. 25 oC)

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Effect of temperature
sections.text:
It is important to investigate the effect of temperature on adsorption in a view of practical
applications. Fig. 10 shows the relationship between the temperature and the percent of removal of HA by Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles. As indicated in Fig. 10, the percent of removal increases with increasing of the temperature.
This behavior confirms that the removal process of HA using Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-
particles is endothermic. This observation can be attributed to increasing of the mobility of the HA molecules and rate of diffusion of adsorbate molecules across the surface of adsorbent with increasing temperature, which leads to an increase in the adsorption capacity of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles (Mohammadi et al., 2014).
Fig. 10. The effect of temperature on HA removal from aqueous solution (volume 50 mL, conc. 20 mg/L, dosage 0.05 g and shaking speed 150 rpm)
The adsorption percentage of HA on Fe3O4 nano-particles, pure chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles at pH 4.02 and 25 oC are shown in Fig. 11. It was shown that the HA adsorption percentage for Fe3O4 nano-particles, pure chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nanoparticles increased with increasing the contact time. It was also shown that the HA adsorption percentage for Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was much higher than that for Fe3O4 nanoparticles and pure chitosan, indicating that surface modification of Fe3O4 nano-particles enhances the HA adsorption capacity. When Fe3O4 being hybrid to the chitosan to make Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles then the surface of this adsorbent would be consisted of Fe3O4 as well as chitosan together works synergistically to each other, therefore the adsorption site did not only depend on the Fe3O4 sites but also depend on the chitosan site altogether. Therefore the results in this study showed that the adsorption capacity of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was higher than the adsorption capacity of each its component self, because there was a synergism effect between the adsorption capacity of chitosan and the adsorption capacity of Fe3O4 when both compounds were being made as hybrid.
Fig. 11. Adsorption percentage of HA from aqueous solution using Fe3O4 nano-particles, pure chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles (volume 50 mL, dosage 0.05 g, pH 4.00, shaking speed 150 rpm and temp. 25 oC)

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Isotherm adsorption
sections.text:
Analysis of isotherm data is very important for predicting the adsorption capacity and
adsorption behavior of adsorbent. In this work, the Langmuir and Freundlich equations were employed to simulate the adsorption isotherms. Langmuir isotherm assumes that adsorption occurs at specific homogenous sites within the adsorbent. Once a HA molecule occupies a certain site, then no further adsorption will take place at the site. The non-linear Langmuir equation can be represented as follows:

Fig. 12. Isotherm curve for HA removal from aqueous solution (contact time: 60 min., volume 50 mL, dosage 0.05 g and shaking speed 150 rpm and temp. 25 oC).
The Freundlich equilibrium isotherm equation was also used to describe experimental
adsorption data. This isotherm is an empirical equation which is used for the description of multilayer adsorption with interaction between adsorbed molecules. The Freundlich equation can be written as:
qe = KfCe 1/n (4)
where Ce is the equilibrium concentration (mg/L), qe is amount of adsorbate adsorbed per unit weight of absorbent (mg/g) and Kf and n are Freundlich constants. A value of 1/n, ranging
between 0 and 1, is a measure of adsorption intensity or surface heterogeneity. A value for n greater than one indicates of a favourable adsorption process. The other Freundlich constant Kf indicates the adsorption capacity of the adsorbent.
The isotherm parameters obtained from the Langmuir and Freundlich models and the
fittings of these models to the experimental data for the HA adsorption onto the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles are given in Fig 12 and tabulated in Table 3. From Fig 12, it can be seen that the adsorption process could be better fitted with the Langmuir isotherm model, which indicated the homogeneous distribution of active sites on the surface of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles. Moreover the adsorption of each adsorbate molecule onto the surface had equal adsorption activation energy and the maximum adsorption capacity (qm) was 44.84 mg/g.

sections.text:

The pseudo-second-order kinetic model is also analyzed to fit the data and given by:

sections.heading: 3.2.9. Application for a real sample
sections.text:
In this study we also investigation of adsorption of HA from peat water (a real sample)
using Fe3O4 nano-particles, pure chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles as adsorbents and its results are given in Fig 15. From Fig 15, it can be seen that the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has higher adsorption percentage than both Fe3O4 nano-particles and pure chitosan. The higher adsorption percentage of peat water onto the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nanoparticles surface is due to the presence of the more available adsorption site with suitable pore size fitted to the size of compounds containing in peat water, such as humic acid, within Fe3O4chitosan hybrid nano-particles compares to Fe3O4 nano-particles and pure chitosan. The other reason is that the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles provides more various functional groups
interactions with compounds containing in peat water compares to the functional groups within the structure of Fe3O4 nano-particles and pure chitosan.
Fig. 15. Adsorption of HA from peat water onto Fe3O4 nano-particles (1), pure chitosan (2) and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles (3) adsorbents

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles with core-shell structure have been prepared.
The characterization of synthesized the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was performed using FTIR, XRD, SEM, TEM, EDX, BET and TGA. The characterization results indicated that chitosan was successfully coated onto the surface of Fe3O4 and did not cause any changes in its structure. The adsorption equilibrium of humic acid (HA) from aqueous solutions using Fe3O4chitosan hybrid nano-particles could be reached at about 60 minutes. The percentage of sorption increases with an increase in the adsorbent dosage as well as decreased with the increasing of initial concentration and its optimum adsorption occurred at pH 4.00. Adsorption isotherms were better fitted by Langmuir isotherm with adsorption capacity was found to be 44.84 mg/g. The results of the kinetic study show that the adsorption of HA onto Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nanoparticles could be described by the pseudo-second order kinetic model with a rate constant in the range of 0.032 to 0.104 g.mg-1.min-1, respectively. Thermodynamic parameters data indicated that the HA adsorption process was non-spontaneous and endothermic under the experimental conditions, with the Gibbs free energy (∆Go) values in the range of 2.92 to 4.65 kJ mol-1, the values of enthalpy (∆Ho), entropy (∆So) and activation energy (Ea) of 21.80 kJ mol -1, 57.55 J mol-1 and 19.27 kJ mol-1, respectively. From the computational chemistry study showed that the
interaction between adsorbate and HA was occurred through the interaction between amine groups of chitosan and phenol groups of HA. The adsorption of HA from peat water (a real sample) using Fe3O4 nano-particles, pure chitosan and Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles shows that the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles has higher adsorption percentage than both Fe3O4 nano-particles and pure chitosan.

metadata.abstractText: The adsorbent of Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles have been prepared. In this process, these materials were initially synthesized by chemical co-precipitation and then cross-linked with chitosan to coat on the surface of Fe3O4 nano-particles. The characterization of the synthesized Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles was performed using FTIR, XRD, TEM, EDX, BET and TGA. Finally, the Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles were used for the adsorption of humic acid (HA) from aqueous solutions using batch adsorption technique. The influences of contact time, pH, adsorbent dosages, initial concentration of HA and temperatures on the adsorption process were studied. The adsorption isotherms were better fitted by Langmuir isotherm with the adsorption capacity was found to be 44.84 mg/g. The results of the kinetic study showed that the adsorption of HA onto Fe3O4-chitosan hybrid nano-particles could be described by the pseudo second order kinetic model with a rate constant in the range of 0.032 to 0.104 g.mg.min, respectively. Thermodynamic parameters data indicated that the HA adsorption process was non spontaneous and endothermic under the experimental conditions, with the values of Gibbs free energy (ΔG) were in the range of 2.92 to 4.65 kJ mol; as well as the values of enthalpy (ΔH), entropy (ΔS) and the activation energy (Ea) were found to be 21.80 kJ mol , 57.55 J mol and 19.27 kJ mol, respectively.
